member.name: F:WasaCommunity.Helpers.MediaTypeNames.ApplicationXJavascript
member.summary: Used to denote the encoding necessary for files containing JavaScript source code. The alternative MIME type for this file type is text/javascript.

member.name: F:WasaCommunity.Helpers.MediaTypeNames.AudioL24
member.summary: 24bit Linear PCM audio at 8-48kHz, 1-N channels; Defined in RFC 3190

member.name: F:WasaCommunity.Helpers.MediaTypeNames.ApplicationXShockwaveFlash
member.summary: Adobe Flash files for example with the extension .swf

member.name: F:WasaCommunity.Helpers.MediaTypeNames.ApplicationOctetStream
member.summary: Arbitrary binary data.[5] Generally speaking this type identifies files that are not associated with a specific application. Contrary to past assumptions by software packages such as Apache this is not a type that should be applied to unknown files. In such a case, a server or application should not indicate a content type, as it may be incorrect, but rather, should omit the type in order to allow the recipient to guess the type.[6]

member.summary: Cascading Style Sheets; Defined in RFC 2318

member.summary: commands; subtype resident in Gecko browsers like Firefox 3.5

member.summary: Comma-separated values; Defined in RFC 4180

member.name: F:WasaCommunity.Helpers.MediaTypeNames.ApplicationJavascript
member.summary: ECMAScript/JavaScript; Defined in RFC 4329 (equivalent to application/ecmascript but with looser processing rules) It is not accepted in IE 8 or earlier - text/javascript is accepted but it is defined as obsolete in RFC 4329. The "type" attribute of the script tag in HTML5 is optional and in practice omitting the media type of JavaScript programs is the most interoperable solution since all browsers have always assumed the correct default even before HTML5.

member.name: F:WasaCommunity.Helpers.MediaTypeNames.ApplicationEcmascript
member.summary: ECMAScript/JavaScript; Defined in RFC 4329 (equivalent to application/javascript but with stricter processing rules)

member.summary: EDI EDIFACT data; Defined in RFC 1767

member.summary: EDI X12 data; Defined in RFC 1767

member.name: F:WasaCommunity.Helpers.MediaTypeNames.TextJavascript
member.summary: JavaScript - Defined in and obsoleted by RFC 4329 in order to discourage its usage in favor of application/javascript. However,text/javascript is allowed in HTML 4 and 5 and, unlike application/javascript, has cross-browser support. The "type" attribute of the script tag in HTML5 is optional and there is no need to use it at all since all browsers have always assumed the correct default (even in HTML 4 where it was required by the specification).

member.name: F:WasaCommunity.Helpers.MediaTypeNames.ImagePjpeg
